title: How is information saved on an SSD? - Quora

response.answer_text: A SSD uses flash memory similar to RAM, but does not clear when powered off, like RAM. SSDs use a grid of electrical cells to quickly send and recieve data, which have 2 positions, 1 or 0, or On and Off respectively, which is how a disc harddrive also works. When data is stored, these cells are either on or off. When the harddrive is being read, the computer’s compiler knows how each combination of switches signifies a command, like how ‘a’ is stored as ‘ 01100001’ where each number is called a bit, and 8 bits make 1 byte. So it takes 1 string of 8 numbers for the computer to store the letter ‘a,’ or any letter for that matter.
